questions.questionText: A ride-sharing app stores trips in Trips(trip_id, driver_id, start_time, end_time). A query should return drivers who completed more than 3 trips in a single day. Which is correct?
options: SELECT driver_id, COUNT() FROM Trips WHERE COUNT()>3;
SELECT driver_id FROM Trips GROUP BY driver_id HAVING COUNT(driver_id)>3;
SELECT driver_id, DATE(start_time), COUNT() FROM Trips GROUP BY driver_id, DATE(start_time) HAVING COUNT()>3;
questions.correctAnswer: SELECT driver_id, DATE(start_time), COUNT() FROM Trips GROUP BY driver_id, DATE(start_time) HAVING COUNT()>3;

questions.questionText: In a hotel database: Bookings(booking_id, room_no, guest_id). A query returns rooms booked more than once. Which is correct?
options: SELECT room_no, COUNT() FROM Bookings GROUP BY room_no HAVING COUNT()>1;
SELECT room_no FROM Bookings WHERE COUNT(*)>1;
SELECT room_no FROM Bookings GROUP BY guest_id;
questions.correctAnswer: SELECT room_no, COUNT() FROM Bookings GROUP BY room_no HAVING COUNT()>1;

questions.questionText: A company stores customer records in a database. Each customer must have a unique email ID, and no duplicates should be allowed. Which database constraint enforces this rule?
You created a DB table Sessions(session_id, user_id, login_time, logout_time). Which SQL retrieves users logged in more than 2 hours?
options: SELECT user_id FROM Sessions WHERE TIMESTAMPDIFF(HOUR, login_time, logout_time) > 2;
SELECT user_id FROM Sessions WHERE DATEDIFF(logout_time, login_time) > 2;
SELECT user_id FROM Sessions WHERE logout_time - login_time > 2;
SELECT * FROM Sessions WHERE login_time > logout_time + 2;
questions.correctAnswer: SELECT user_id FROM Sessions WHERE TIMESTAMPDIFF(HOUR, login_time, logout_time) > 2;

questions.questionText: You’re designing a ride-booking app. Each driver can serve one rider at a time, and each rider must be assigned a driver. Which type of relationship and constraint fits best in DBMS schema?
options: One-to-One with NOT NULL and UNIQUE
questions.correctAnswer: One-to-One with NOT NULL and UNIQUE

questions.questionText: A large e-commerce platform stores images of products. To save space, it decides to avoid storing the same image multiple times. Instead, it stores a reference based on a hash value of the image content. Which database design concept is being applied?

A startup maintains a database of customer orders with tables Orders(order_id, customer_id, amount) and Customers(customer_id, country). They want to find the total amount spent by customers from each country who have placed more than 5 orders. Which SQL query achieves this?
options: SELECT C.country, SUM(O.amount) FROM Orders O JOIN Customers C ON O.customer_id = C.customer_id GROUP BY C.country HAVING COUNT(O.order_id) > 5;
SELECT country, COUNT(order_id) FROM Orders O JOIN Customers C ON O.customer_id=C.customer_id GROUP BY country;
SELECT country, SUM(amount) FROM Orders O JOIN Customers C ON O.customer_id=C.customer_id;
SELECT country, SUM(amount) FROM Customers GROUP BY country HAVING COUNT(order_id)>5;
questions.correctAnswer: SELECT C.country, SUM(O.amount) FROM Orders O JOIN Customers C ON O.customer_id = C.customer_id GROUP BY C.country HAVING COUNT(O.order_id) > 5;

questions.questionText: In a database of customer orders, you must ensure that deleting a customer will also delete all their associated orders. Which SQL feature provides this behavior automatically?
Your SQL query returns multiple duplicate rows when joining 3 normalized tables. Business logic is correct. What's a common cause of this issue?
options: Implicit many-to-many due to multiple foreign key paths
questions.correctAnswer: Implicit many-to-many due to multiple foreign key paths

questions.questionText: A database query meant to fetch active users: SELECT * FROM users WHERE last_login > NOW() - INTERVAL '30 days' AND status = 'active'; Returns inconsistent rows across calls. What’s a likely cause?
options: NOW() gets evaluated differently per row
questions.correctAnswer: NOW() gets evaluated differently per row
